{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-215-02-A |Item_parent=Purpuras in adults and children |Item_parent_short=Purpuras in adults and children |Rank=A |Title=Knowing how to differentiate vascular purpura from thrombocytopenic purpura |Description=None |Rubric=Positive diagnosis |Contributors= |Order=2}} Two main mechanisms: - '''Vascular purpura = pathology of the vascular wall'' = most often infiltrated o by inflammation of the wall (vasculitis) o by fragility of the capillary vascular wall - '''Thrombocytopenic purpura''' = '''primary haemostasis disorder''' (especially thrombocytopenia ('''[[Platelet abnormality SD-215|platelet abnormality]]'''), possibly thrombopathy) = usually non-infiltrated and non-confluent
{| class="wikitable" | |Vascular purpura of vasculitis |'''Vascular purpura due to capillary fragility*''''' |'''Thrombocytopenic purpura''' |- |Mechanism |Inflammation of the vascular wall |Fragility of the vascular wall |Thrombocytopenia (platelet abnormality) (more rarely thrombopathy) |- |Usual clinical appearance |infiltrated, sometimes necrotic |Non-infiltrated, non-necrotic |Non-infiltrated, non-necrotic |- |Distribution |Declive, predominantly in the lower limbs Aggravated by orthostatism No mucosal involvement |No elevation, areas of friction (perifollicular in scurvy) Mucosal involvement possible (gingivorrhagia) |May affect all areas but predominates in declining areas Mucosal damage possible |- |''Other bleeding sites''' |No |Yes (gingivorrhagia possible in scurvy) |Yes (haematomas, ecchymoses, epistaxis, gingivorrhages, intra-oral haemorrhagic bullae or visceral haemorrhages) |} * Vascular purpura due to non-vascular capillary fragility (hypercorticism, scurvy, Bateman purpura ...)

properties.question: How can vascular purpura due to capillary fragility be differentiated from thrombocytopenic purpura?
properties.option_a: Both conditions are characterized by infiltrated and necrotic lesions.
properties.option_b: Vascular purpura due to capillary fragility often involves areas of friction and may show mucosal involvement.
properties.option_c: Thrombocytopenic purpura is typically non-infiltrated, non-necrotic, and may present with mucosal damage such as gingivorrhagia.
properties.option_d: Thrombocytopenic purpura is usually aggravated by orthostatism and does not involve mucosal areas.
